newsitem.title: GERMANY: ATHLETICS-SPAIN'S ANTON WINS IN BERLIN ON MARATHON DEBUT.
newsitem.headline: ATHLETICS-SPAIN'S ANTON WINS IN BERLIN ON MARATHON DEBUT.

text.p: Spain's European 10,000 metres champion Abel Anton, making his debut in a marathon, broke away with less than two km remaining to win the 23rd annual Berlin marathon on Sunday.
Cheered on by huge crowds totalling more than two million, Anton won in 2 hours nine minutes and 15 seconds and collected the first place prize of 30,000 marks ($20,000).
It was the ninth fastest marathon of 1996, although the flat and fast Berlin course has produced three world year best times since 1990.
Francis Naaly of Tanzania finished 21 seconds behind Anton in second place with a time of 2:09.36. Last year's winner, Sammy Lelei of Kenya, was a disappointing third in 2:09.52.
Lelei had won last year's race in 2:07.02 -- the second fastest marathon time ever run -- and had started Sunday's race brimming with optimism about an even faster run.
With 19,532 runners from 70 countries, Berlin is the world's third largest marathon after New York and London.
Anton said: "When we hit the 40-km point, I knew I could win. With the success I had here today, I think I will concentrate on the marathon more in the future. I believe I can run it in under 2:08."
Colleen de Reuck of South Africa won the women's race in 2:26:36, but made it only a few steps past the finish line before being sick.
Renata Kokowska of Poland was second in 2:27.41 and Marlene Renders of Belgium third in 2:27.42.
De Reuck, who lowered her previous best marathon time by more than five minutes, said: "I went out a little bit too fast and that's I think why I had some problems later."
